div.p: Yeah, my mum and dad they were great parents they were very supportive, they always sort of pushed me to do well and tried to recognise
what you were good at and support you in that; they were also good if you did things wrong they would always tell you off appropriately
not sort of let anything slide and I think that’s important when you’re growing up. They were always there for you and it wasn’t them
that was a problem with me it was me, I sort of went out and made a lot of bad decisions which I don’t think they were, I think it
disappointed them a lot I think but it’s good now because we all sort of get on again and obviously I left home at a young age because
I was quite disruptive in the family, I had no regard for rules, no respect for particularly any other and I think a lot of that was to do with
my substance misuse and I’ve got a sister and it wasn’t doing her any good being around it so that’s when I left home...
I left home because it was me, it wasn’t my family, I want to stress that, you know, I had a really good family and it was just the best decision
and I still think it was a good decision that I did leave home even now, even although I think sometimes it was such a mistake
I’ve learnt a lot from living independently and it made me be way more self-sufficient and actually do things for myself and go and get myself training
and get myself into a job rather than expecting things off my parents and dossing around at home so eventually I did sort of get back onto the straight and
narrow through the help of various programme officers and help, you know, with substance abuse and things just to get your mind back in the right
place and then eventually I got back in contact with my family and they helped me through it as well and it’s hard, it’s very hard being young I think
and no-one says it’s easy but you’ve just got to keep looking to the future I think and just keep thinking you need to do something
because no-one else, it’s down to you, no-one else is going to help you, no-one else is going to make you anything you’ve got to put the
hard work in and I think when you realise that and as long as you have got solid people there to guide you you can do it, you can do what you want to do
and I was lucky enough to have all those people around to help and put the hard work in and while I was in supported housing
still got on and did my apprenticeship and got through it and had the solid ground there to get a job and to do well.
